title: 103_s2139
content:
The Act titled "West Virginia Rivers Conservation Act of 1994" amends various sections related to national rivers and recreation areas in West Virginia, including the New River Gorge National River, Gauley River National Recreation Area, and Bluestone National Scenic River. It also designates the Upper New River in West Virginia. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act is amended to designate the Upper New River in West Virginia as a scenic river, exempting it from acreage limitations and allowing for improvements to existing roads. Ownership jurisdiction over federal lands within the designated segment is transferred to the Secretary of the Interior. Ownership jurisdiction over federal lands within the designated segment is transferred to the Secretary of the Interior, subject to the existing lease between the United States and the State of West Virginia for the Bluestone Wildlife Management Area. The State of West Virginia retains management of hunting, fishing, and other wildlife activities in the area as permitted in the lease agreement. The Secretary shall renew the lease agreement upon request with the same terms and conditions. The Secretary may terminate or modify the lease agreement and assume administrative authority over the designated segment if requested by the State of West Virginia. This designation does not affect the management of the Bluestone project or the authority of any US department to carry out the project's purposes. Designation of Elk River as a study river. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a study of the Elk River segment in West Virginia to determine its eligibility for inclusion in the national wild and scenic rivers system, National Park System as a national river, or as a national recreation area. A report on the study's results must be submitted to the Senate and House committees within 3 years. Effect on Management: This section does not impact the management of the Sutton project or the authority of any US department to carry out its purposes. Consultation: The Secretary will consult with the West Virginia Division of Tourism and Parks and the West Virginia Division of Environmental Protection during the study. SEC. 7. CONSOLIDATED MANAGEMENT.

The Secretary of the Interior will consolidate offices and personnel for efficient administration of the New River segment with other nearby areas. 

SEC. 8. MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS.

Title XI of the National Parks and Recreation Act of 1978 is amended to include new provisions. The West Virginia National Interest River Conservation Act of 1987 applies to the New River Gorge National River in the same way as the Gauley River National Recreation Area. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act is amended regarding leases. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act is amended regarding leases for the New River Gorge National River in West Virginia. The Secretary may renew, terminate, or modify lease agreements upon request by the State of West Virginia. SEC. 9. GAULEY ACCESS.

The Secretary must submit a plan for river access for noncommercial recreational users in the Gauley River National Recreation Area within 90 days. Access should utilize existing public roads and rights-of-way to the maximum extent feasible.

SEC. 10. VISITOR CENTER. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to construct a visitor center and related facilities near the confluence of the New River and Gauley River to enhance visitor experience. The center can be built outside the boundaries of the National River and Recreation Area if no suitable site is available within. SEC. 11. EXTENSION. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act provisions will apply to Bluestone and Meadow Rivers for 5 years, starting from the enactment date. This includes river segments eligible for designation but not included in previous acts.

SEC. 12. BLUESTONE RIVER PUBLIC ACCESS. SEC. 12. BLUESTONE RIVER PUBLIC ACCESS. The Secretary may negotiate agreements or acquire lands to provide public access and parking for the Bluestone River while preserving its natural values. SEC. 13. GAULEY RIVER BOUNDARY MODIFICATION. Amendment to the West Virginia National Interest River Conservation Act of 1987 regarding project construction and license surrender implications on boundary modification.
